question.translation[0].definitions[0].d: a sentence or phrase that is used to ask for information or to test someone’s knowledge
question.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Can I ask you a question?
I’m afraid I can’t answer that question.
They asked me quite a lot of difficult questions about my job.
The survey included questions on age and smoking habits.
In answer to your last question, ‘Yes’.
question.translation[0].definitions[1].d: a subject or problem that needs to be discussed or dealt with
question.translation[0].definitions[1].e: This raises the question of government funding.
an urgent need to address the question of crime
Several questions have still not been resolved.
The question is should I take the job in Japan, or should I stay here?
Some important questions remain unanswered (=still have not been dealt with or explained).
We discussed the question of confidentiality.
question.translation[0].definitions[2].d: if there is some question about something, there is doubt about it, or people feel uncertain about it
question.translation[0].definitions[2].e: The exact cause of death is still open to question (=not certain).
He’s by far the best candidate, there’s no question about it (=it is completely certain).
There is no question that (=it is completely certain that) the government knew about the deal.
This has called into question people’s right to retire at 60.
Her efficiency and intelligence are beyond question.
There are questions about the system’s practicality.
question.translation[0].note_box[0].head: – Meaning 1: a sentence or phrase that is used to ask for information or to test someone’s knowledge
question.translation[0].note_box[0].sect: Don’t be afraid to ask questions.
I just have one question: is the treatment effective?
He poses the question, ‘What should we teach our children?’
I recently put some of these questions to a psychologist.
He had skilfully evaded Margie’s questions.
He used to set the questions for a TV quiz show.
He didn’t answer, so I rephrased my question.
They bombarded him with questions about the case.
He fielded questions from reporters about the announcement.
Some of the questions in the last section were very difficult.
These questions should be easy for you.
Did you win, or is that a stupid question?
How can we keep the press from asking awkward questions?
The media began to ask embarrassing questions about MPs' expenses.
Can I ask you a personal question?
All you have to do is answer the three simple questions below.
The immigration officer asked me some searching questions.
She was startled by the direct question.
You have to answer twenty exam questions.
She did not answer the maid’s impertinent question.
question.translation[0].note_box[1].head: – Meaning 2: a subject or problem that needs to be discussed or dealt with
question.translation[0].note_box[1].sect: raise a question
This study raises several important questions.
address a question
Two questions need to be addressed.
discuss a question
They discussed the question of the possible use of the atomic bomb.
consider a question
We must also consider the question of compensation.
deal with a question
This question will be dealt with in Chapter 4.
tackle a question
Who has the ability to tackle the tough questions facing the nation?
resolve a question
We will proceed just as soon as we can resolve the question of the fee.
an important/big question
The book raises important questions about nationality and the role of a citizen.
a fundamental question
Their experiences have highlighted fundamental questions of human rights.
serious questions
The incident has raised serious questions about police conduct.
a vexed/thorny question
Finally, there’s the thorny question of money.
a burning question
Little progress was made on the burning question of Africa’s debt.
a moral/ethical question
This area of medical research poses serious ethical questions that doctors alone cannot answer.
unanswered/open
At this point a key question remains unanswered.
question.translation[0].note_box[2].head: – Meaning 3: if there is some question about something, there is doubt about it, or people feel uncertain about it
question.translation[0].note_box[2].sect: Whether he will survive politically is open to question.
He brought into question all the principles on which the Soviet system was based.
The special protection given to these animals has come into question in recent years.
There’s no question that they have done an outstanding job.
question.translation[0].note_box[3].sect: something that you ask someone, either when speaking or when writing
Would anyone like to ask any questions?
I’ve emailed the hotel with one or two questions.
a question that you ask when you are not sure you have understood something or that the information you have is correct
If you have any queries, please contact your travel agent.
Our staff are always available to answer customers’ queries.
a question you ask in order to get information or find out the details about something
We’ve advertised the house, and we’ve already received lots of enquiries.
The police have been making some inquiries in the area.
a polite or formal question asking for something that you want or need
The bank said ‘no’ to our request for more money.
You must make your request in writing.
question.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to ask someone questions in order to get information about something such as a crime
question.translation[1].definitions[0].e: Two men have been arrested and questioned.
She hates being questioned about her past.
Joseph questioned the doctors closely (=asked them a lot of questions).
question.translation[1].definitions[1].d: to have or express doubts about whether something is true, good, necessary etc
question.translation[1].definitions[1].e: Are you questioning what I’m saying?
No one dared to question his decisions.
One questions whether he’s telling the truth.
question.translation[1].note_box[0].sect: question
to ask someone questions in order to get information about something such as a crime
The police questioned him for three hours before releasing him without charge.
When questioned by reporters, he denied all knowledge about the affair.
interrogate
to keep asking a lot of questions for a long time, sometimes using threats, in order to get information
He was interrogated by US agents about his alleged links to al-Qaeda.
interview
to ask someone questions for a newspaper, TV programme etc, or to ask someone questions to find out if they are suitable for a job, course etc
Did you hear him being interviewed on ‘the Today Programme’?
The woman who interviewed me offered me the job.
grill
to ask someone a lot of difficult questions about something, in a way that is tiring or annoying
She started grilling me about why I was so late coming home.
cross-examine
to ask someone a series of questions in court about their previous statements, in order to find out whether they have been telling the truth
The defence lawyer cross-examined the witness in order to test his evidence.
be helping police with their inquiries
to be questioned by the police about a crime – used especially in news reports when the police think that this person may be guilty of the crime
Last night, a 21-year-old woman was helping police with their inquiries.
question.translation[2].definitions[0].d: a sentence or phrase that asks for information
question.translation[2].definitions[0].e: They asked me a lot of questions about my work experience.
Don’t hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.
question.translation[2].definitions[1].d: a subject or problem that needs to be settled, discussed, or dealt with
question.translation[2].definitions[1].e: The real question is whether the employee has any power over customers.
This whole question of measuring risk has became a mess.
question.translation[2].definitions[2].d: a feeling of doubt about something
question.translation[2].definitions[2].e: This incident raises further questions about airport security.
He is by far the best candidate. There is no question about it.
The wisdom of this policy is open to question (=it will be doubted by some people).
question.translation[2].definitions[3].d: the things, people etc in question are the ones that are being discussed or talked about
question.translation[2].definitions[3].e: Is the information in question really a business secret?
question.translation[2].definitions[4].e: The idea of merging with another company was now out of the question.
question.translation[3].definitions[0].d: to ask someone questions to find out what they know about something
question.translation[3].definitions[0].e: None of the defendants was questioned by the police before their arrest.
We have questioned many of our customers about the new services.
question.translation[3].definitions[1].d: to have doubts about whether something is true or if it is the right thing to do
question.translation[3].definitions[1].e: The report questioned ISC’s heavy reliance on three international customers.
